channel.title: Pacman (Arch's package manager) sucks
channel.description:
My cousin gave me his broken laptop, I fixed it and decided to install Arch (i686). I chose the ftp installation and everything went smoothly. I went to install KDE:
pacman -S kde
It downloaded all of the packages and installed them, I added 'hal' to the start daemons in rc.conf and then edited initab to boot into X, and also start kdm. This flat out didn't work, I tried a few more things until I realized that xorg wasn't even installed?
pacman -S xorg
Fixed the problem, but what kind of dependency checking does pacman do if it doesn't even install the X server when you request a window manager to be installed? Apt-get in debian certainly can manage a simple task like that, so what is the deal you arch guru's? (Mopman)
All I can figure is I either have something configured wrong, or pacman flat out sucks...

item.title: Pacman (Arch's package manager) sucks
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

The $PATH variable is handled through /etc/profile, so all you have to do is open a new terminal (or run source /etc/profile" if you don’t want to reopen your terminal at the current time) - not log in and log back out. If brand new terminals aren’t getting the proper $PATH, you have set your terminal emulator up incorrectly (certain terms don’t act as login shells by default, cough gnome terminal).

The /opt thing is used for programs which do not adhere to the standard filesystem hierarchy and wouldn’t fit with the rest of the system if they were put there. KDE was once in /opt, although if I remember correctly the issues Arch had with the hierarchy were fixed and it is now in the main filesystem.

The symlink issue is again, a philosophy thing. Personally that sounds like a horrible hack to me, but I can see where some people might see otherwise. Same with the dependency thing, I’d be pissed if pacman -S kde pulled in the xorg metapackage Different strokes for different folks I guess.

item.title: Pacman (Arch's package manager) sucks
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

Alright, one last complaint about Arch. I install java with pacman, try to run a java program and ‘java cannot be found’. The problem is that java is installed in /opt/java, and instead of doing the decent thing and putting a symlink to the executable in the path (/usr/sbin/ for instance), it adds itself to the path. This wouldn’t be a problem unless you prefer not to log out and log back in every time you install a new program (ie, if you run a server, or find it very annoying)

However, like Mopman said it is really just the philosophy of arch v debian, these are just things I find annoying. An arch user may well find things that annoy them with debian, I don’t know.

Summary:

Things I like about Arch:

  1. Most of rc.conf, particlarly the module and daemon array.
  2. The AUR is a great idea, wish debian had similar.

Things I don’t:

  1. All dependancies of a given program aren’t installed when you install that program, a problem with repositories and philosophy.
  2. Must refresh $PATH variable manually, shouldn’t pacman do that at least?

Thats a short list, I’m happy I tried Arch, but I’ll move back to debian, thanks.

item.title: Pacman (Arch's package manager) sucks
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

No, that’s not what it is.

Arch supplies unbranded firefox, because they have to in order to stay within the terms of the license (because they apply a few patches). This is similar to debians “iceweasel”, except that arch just uses the compile-time option that mozilla provide. It’s exactly the same as the official firefox release, just without the logos and “Firefox” name. (And +archs patches, which afaik is just something to do with a custom xulrunner)

item.title: Pacman (Arch's package manager) sucks
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

For a start, that would be a problem with the repositories, not pacman

It’s also not a problem at all. Xorg is not a dependency for KDE, a dependency is something required for the program to run. You need an X server of course, but what if you want to use XFree86? More commonly, what if you are running remote?

I suppose they could have solved the second one by putting xorg-clients in the dependencies, but that still wouldn’t pull in xorg-server so wouldn’t do what you want anyway.
